meanings.definition: To cause someone to feel disgust or revulsion.
meanings.sent1: The sight of rotten food can be very sicking to some people.
meanings.sent2: The smell of the garbage was so sicking that I had to leave the room.
meanings.sent3: The idea of eating bugs might be sicking to some, but they are a good source of protein.
meanings.sent4: The corruption in the government is sicking, like a festering wound that never heals.
meanings.sent5: The graphic horror movie was sicking, leaving the audience trembling in fear.

meanings.definition: To expel something from the stomach through the mouth.
meanings.sent1: After eating too much, he ended up sicking all over the floor.
meanings.sent2: She felt nauseous and knew she would end up sicking soon.
meanings.sent3: The baby ended up sicking on his new outfit, much to his mother's dismay.
meanings.sent4: The roller coaster made her feel like she was going to sicking out her lunch.
meanings.sent5: The food poisoning caused her to spend the night sicking up everything she had eaten.

meanings.definition: To be in the process of vomiting.
meanings.sent1: She was sicking in the bathroom for hours after eating the spoiled food.
meanings.sent2: The flu made him feel like he was constantly sicking.
meanings.sent3: The motion sickness on the boat had her sicking over the side.
meanings.sent4: The bad seafood had everyone on the trip sicking over the railings.
meanings.sent5: The smell of the garbage had her sicking before she even entered the room.
